September 18, 1929.
To the Hon. Milo H. Kent
chairmen of the Airport Committee,
Board of Supervisors,
Gary or San Francisco,
California.
sir:
Inasmuch as the Chairmen of the advisory Committee on
Aviation to the City of San Francisco, is leaving on a trip to
Europe, which will consume at least two months time, a meeting of
the Advisory Committee was held on this date, in order that this
report could be furnished to you of the unanimous sentiment, feel-
ings and recommendations of the Advisory Conmittee.
In case you, or the Board of supervisors, find it
necessary to possess any further details regarding the attitude
of this (
Committee, during my absence, you can call upon Lieutenant-
Colonel Gerald
the Committee,
C. Brant, or B. B.
Mouton.
for siren information.
the other members of
There 1s no divergence of
opinion among the members of this committee, and any statement or
recommendations they may make can be considered as naving my
heartiest endorsement and approval.
On March 26th last, Mr. Mershall Hale, President of the
Down Town Association, stated that he had recommended me, as Chair-
of the Aviation Committee :
of the Down Town Association,
to be
a member of the advisory Committee on Aviation, to be appointed by
the Mayor.
On April 8th last, I read in the newspapers that such
committee had been appointed, consisting of Lieutenent-Colonel
Gerald C. Brant and B. E. Mouton and myself , but that vou had ex-
pressed some uncertainty as co the possibility of securing Colonel
Brant, or Mr. Mouton, because of their federal connections.
called you on the telephone several times between that date and
the date of the first meeting of
and was informed by
not yet been definitely determined, because of War Department object-
lons to the service of colonel Brant on the committee.
When our Advisory Committee finally did meet with your
Airport Committee in joint conference, on May 3, 1929, at the Palace
Hotel, the entire situation was informally discussed.
The members
of our Committee were in agreement with the facts presented by you
that Mills Field, if properly developed, would make a satisfactory
aviation base (as distinguished from aviation terminal).
